Play a sample referenced by its name.
				Optionally, the playback can be made "unique" to force stopping all other samples currently played. The voices allocated for playback will then be returned.
methods.name: play

methods.description: Stop a given voice.
methods.name: stop

methods.description: Stop all playing voices.
methods.name: stop_all

methods.description: Set the mix rate (in Hz) of a given voice.
methods.name: set_mix_rate

methods.description: Set the pitch scale of a given voice. A ratio of 1.0 is the normal scale.
methods.name: set_pitch_scale

methods.description:
Set the volume of a given voice using a linear scale.
				The "volume" argument should be a positive factor ranging from 0.0 (mute) up to 16.0 (i.e. 24 dB).
				A factor of 1.0 means that the voice will be played at normal system volume. Factors above 1.0 might be limited by the platform's audio output.
methods.name: set_volume

methods.description:
Set the volume of a given voice in dB.
				The "dB" argument can range from -80 to 24 dB, 0 dB being the maximum volume. Every 6 dB (resp. -6 dB), the volume is increased (resp. reduced) by half.
methods.name: set_volume_db

methods.description:
Set the panning of a voice. Panning goes from -1.0 (left) to +1.0 (right).
				Optionally, for hardware than support 3D sound, one can also set depth and height (also in range -1.0 to +1.0).
methods.name: set_pan

methods.description:
Set the filter for a given voice, using the given type (see FILTER_* constants), cutoff frequency (from 20 to 16,384 Hz) and resonance (from 0 to 4.0).
				Optionally, a gain can also be given (from 0 to 2.0).
methods.name: set_filter

methods.description: Set the chorus send level of a voice (from 0 to 1.0). For setting chorus parameters, see [AudioServer].
methods.name: set_chorus

methods.description: Set the reverberation type (see REVERB_* constants) and send level (from 0 to 1.0) of a voice.
methods.name: set_reverb

methods.description: Return the current mix rate for a given voice.
methods.name: get_mix_rate

methods.description: Return the current pitch scale for a given voice.
methods.name: get_pitch_scale

methods.description: Return the current volume (on a linear scale) for a given voice.
methods.name: get_volume

methods.description: Return the current volume (in dB) for a given voice.
methods.name: get_volume_db

methods.description: Return the current panning for a given voice.
methods.name: get_pan

methods.description: Return the current pan depth for a given voice.
methods.name: get_pan_depth

methods.description: Return the current pan height for a given voice.
methods.name: get_pan_height

methods.description: Return the current filter type in use (see FILTER_* constants) for a given voice.
methods.name: get_filter_type

methods.description: Return the current filter cutoff frequency for a given voice.
methods.name: get_filter_cutoff

methods.description: Return the current filter resonance for a given voice.
methods.name: get_filter_resonance

methods.description: Return the current filter gain for a given voice.
methods.name: get_filter_gain

methods.description: Return the current chorus send level for a given voice.
methods.name: get_chorus

methods.description: Return the current reverberation room type for a given voice (see REVERB_* enum).
methods.name: get_reverb_room

methods.description: Return the current reverberation send level for a given voice.
methods.name: get_reverb

methods.description: Set the default pitch scale of the player. A ratio of 1.0 is the normal scale.
methods.name: set_default_pitch_scale

methods.description:
Set the default volume of the player using a linear scale.
				The "volume" argument should be a positive factor ranging from 0.0 (mute) up to 16.0 (i.e. 24 dB).
				A factor of 1.0 means that the voice will be played at normal system volume. Factors above 1.0 might be limited by the platform's audio output.
methods.name: set_default_volume

methods.description:
Set the default volume of the player in dB.
				The "dB" argument can range from -80 to 24 dB, 0 dB being the maximum volume. Every 6 dB (resp. -6 dB), the volume is increased (resp. reduced) by half.
methods.name: set_default_volume_db

methods.description:
Set the default panning of the player. Panning goes from -1.0 (left) to +1.0 (right).
				Optionally, for hardware than support 3D sound, one can also set depth and height (also in range -1.0 to +1.0).
methods.name: set_default_pan

methods.description:
Set the default filter for the player, using the given type (see FILTER_* constants), cutoff frequency (from 20 to 16,384 Hz) and resonance (from 0 to 4.0).
			Optionally, a gain can also be given (from 0 to 2.0).
methods.name: set_default_filter

methods.description: Set the default chorus send level of the player (from 0 to 1.0). For setting chorus parameters, see [AudioServer].
methods.name: set_default_chorus

methods.description: Set the default reverberation type (see REVERB_* constants) and send level (from 0 to 1.0) of the player.
methods.name: set_default_reverb

methods.description: Return the default pitch scale of the player.
methods.name: get_default_pitch_scale

methods.description: Return the default volume (on a linear scale) of the player.
methods.name: get_default_volume

methods.description: Return the default volume (in dB) of the player.
methods.name: get_default_volume_db

methods.description: Return the default panning of the player.
methods.name: get_default_pan

methods.description: Return the default pan depth of the player.
methods.name: get_default_pan_depth

methods.description: Return the default pan height of the player.
methods.name: get_default_pan_height

methods.description: Return the default filter type in use (see FILTER_* constants) for the player.
methods.name: get_default_filter_type

methods.description: Return the default filter cutoff frequency of the player.
methods.name: get_default_filter_cutoff

methods.description: Return the default filter resonance of the player.
methods.name: get_default_filter_resonance

methods.description: Return the default filter gain of the player.
methods.name: get_default_filter_gain

methods.description: Return the default chorus send level of the player.
methods.name: get_default_chorus

methods.description: Return the default reverberation room type of the player (see REVERB_* enum).
methods.name: get_default_reverb_room

methods.description: Return the default reverberation send level of the player.

SamplePlayer.description: SamplePlayer is a [Node] meant for simple sample playback. A library of samples is loaded and played back "as is", without positioning or anything.

constants.description: Low-pass filter is used for voice.
constants.name: FILTER_LOWPASS

constants.description: Band-pass filter is used for voice.
constants.name: FILTER_BANDPASS

constants.description: High-pass filter is used for voice.
constants.name: FILTER_HIPASS

constants.description: Notch (band reject) filter is used for voice.
constants.name: FILTER_NOTCH

constants.description: Peak (exclusive band) filter is used for voice.
constants.name: FILTER_PEAK

constants.description: Band-limit filter is used for voice, in this case resonance is the high-pass cutoff. A band-limit filter has a different frequency response than a notch filter, but otherwise both are band-rejecting filters.
constants.name: FILTER_BANDLIMIT

constants.description: Low-shelf filter is used for voice.
constants.name: FILTER_LOW_SHELF

constants.description: High-shelf filter is used for voice.
constants.name: FILTER_HIGH_SHELF

constants.description: Value returned if the voice ID is invalid.
constants.name: INVALID_VOICE_ID

SamplePlayer.name: SamplePlayer

methods.description: Set the [EventStream] this player will play.
methods.name: set_stream

methods.description: Return the currently assigned stream.
methods.name: get_stream

methods.description: Play the currently assigned stream.
methods.name: play

methods.description: Stop playing.
methods.name: stop

methods.description: Return whether this player is playing.
methods.name: is_playing

methods.description: Pause stream playback.
methods.name: set_paused

methods.description: Return whether the playback is currently paused.
methods.name: is_paused

methods.description: Set whether the stream will be restarted at the end.
methods.name: set_loop

methods.description: Return whether this player will be restart the playback at the end.
methods.name: has_loop

methods.description:
Set the playback volume for this player. This is a float between 0.0 (silent) and 1.0 (full volume). Values over 1.0 may amplify sound even more, but may introduce distortion. Negative values may just invert the output waveform, which produces no audible difference.
				The effect of these special values ultimately depends on the low-level implementation of the file format being played.
methods.name: set_volume

methods.description: Return the playback volume for this player.
methods.name: get_volume

methods.description: Set the pitch multiplier for all sounds coming from this stream. A value of 2.0 shifts all pitches one octave up, and a value of 0.5 shifts pitches one octave down.
methods.name: set_pitch_scale

methods.description: Return the pitch scale factor for this player.
methods.name: get_pitch_scale

methods.description: Set the tempo multiplier. This allows to slow down or speed up the music, without affecting its pitch.
methods.name: set_tempo_scale

methods.description: Return the tempo multiplier.
methods.name: get_tempo_scale

methods.description: Set the playback volume for this player, in decibels. This is a float between -80.0 (silent) and 0.0 (full volume). Values under -79.0 get truncated to -80, but values over 0.0 do not, so the warnings for over amplifying (see [method set_volume]) still apply.
methods.name: set_volume_db

methods.description: Return the playback volume for this player, in decibels.
methods.name: get_volume_db

methods.description: Return the name of the currently assigned stream. This is not the file name, but a field inside the file. If no stream is assigned, if returns "<No Stream>".
methods.name: get_stream_name

methods.description: Return the number of times the playback has looped.
methods.name: get_loop_count

methods.description: Return the playback position. May be in seconds, but depends on the stream type.
methods.name: get_pos

methods.description: Set the playback position. May be in seconds, but depends on the stream type.
methods.name: seek_pos

methods.description: Return the song length. May be in seconds, but depends on the stream type.
methods.name: get_length

methods.description: Set whether this player will start playing as soon as it enters the scene tree.
methods.name: set_autoplay

methods.description: Return whether this player will start playing as soon as it enters the scene tree.
methods.name: has_autoplay

methods.description:
Set the volume scale for an individual channel of the stream, with the same value range as [method set_volume]. The channel number depends on the stream format. For example, MIDIs range from 0 to 15, and MODs from 0 to 63.
				Many stream formats are multichannel, so this allows to affect only a part of the music.
methods.name: set_channel_volume

methods.description: Return the volume scale for an individual channel of the stream.
methods.name: get_channel_volume

methods.description: Return the time at which the last note of a given channel in the stream plays.
methods.name: get_channel_last_note_time

EventPlayer.description:
Class for event stream playback. Event streams are music expressed as a series of events (note on, note off, instrument change...), as opposed to audio streams, which are just audio data. Examples of event-based streams are MIDI files, or MOD music.
		Currently, only MOD, S3M, IT, and XM music is supported.
EventPlayer.name: EventPlayer

methods.description: Adds the specified color to the end of the ramp, with the specified offset

methods.name: set_offsets

methods.description: Returns the offsets for the colors in this ramp
methods.name: get_offsets

methods.description: Sets the colors for the specified amount of elements. Calling this function with a different number of elements than previously defined causes the ramp to resize its colors and offsets array to accomodate the new elements.
methods.name: set_colors

methods.description: Returns the colors in the ramp
methods.name: get_colors

ColorRamp.description: Given a set of colors, this node will interpolate them in order, meaning, that if you have color 1, color 2 and color3, the ramp will interpolate (generate the colors between two colors) from color 1 to color 2 and from color 2 to color 3. Initially the ramp will have 2 colors (black and white), one (black) at ramp lower offset offset 0 and the other (white) at the ramp higher offset 1.
ColorRamp.name: ColorRamp

methods.name: Plane

Plane.description: Plane represents a normalized plane equation. Basically, "normal" is the normal of the plane (a,b,c normalized), and "d" is the distance from the origin to the plane (in the direction of "normal"). "Over" or "Above" the plane is considered the side of the plane towards where the normal is pointing.

methods.description: Returns true or false depending on whether the key is pressed or not. You can pass KEY_*, which are pre-defined constants listed in [@Global Scope].

methods.description: Returns true or false depending on whether mouse button is pressed or not. You can pass BUTTON_*, which are pre-defined constants listed in [@Global Scope].

methods.description: Returns if the joystick button at the given index is currently pressed. (see JOY_* constants in [@Global Scope])

methods.description: Returns true or false depending on whether the action event is pressed. Actions and their events can be set in the Project Settings / Input Map tab. Or be set with [InputMap].
methods.name: is_action_pressed

methods.description: Add a new mapping entry (in SDL2 format) to the mapping database. Optionally update already connected devices.
methods.name: add_joy_mapping

methods.description: Removes all mappings from the internal db that match the given uid.
methods.name: remove_joy_mapping

methods.description: Returns if the specified device is known by the system. This means that it sets all button and axis indices exactly as defined in the JOY_* constants (see [@Global Scope]). Unknown joysticks are not expected to match these constants, but you can still retrieve events from them.
methods.name: is_joy_known

methods.description: Returns the current value of the joystick axis at given index (see JOY_* constants in [@Global Scope])
methods.name: get_joy_axis

methods.description: Returns the name of the joystick at the specified device index
methods.name: get_joy_name

methods.description: Returns a SDL2 compatible device guid on platforms that use gamepad remapping. Returns "Default Gamepad" otherwise.
methods.name: get_joy_guid

methods.description: Returns an [Array] containing the device IDs of all currently connected joysticks.

methods.description: Returns the strength of the joystick vibration: x is the strength of the weak motor, and y is the strength of the strong motor.
methods.name: get_joy_vibration_strength

methods.description: Returns the duration of the current vibration effect in seconds.
methods.name: get_joy_vibration_duration

methods.description:
Starts to vibrate the joystick. Joysticks usually come with two rumble motors, a strong and a weak one. weak_magnitude is the strength of the weak motor (between 0 and 1) and strong_magnitude is the strength of the strong motor (between 0 and 1). duration is the duration of the effect in seconds (a duration of 0 will try to play the vibration indefinitely).
				Note that not every hardware is compatible with long effect durations, it is recommended to restart an effect if in need to play it for more than a few seconds.
methods.name: start_joy_vibration

methods.description: Stops the vibration of the joystick.
methods.name: stop_joy_vibration

methods.description: If the device has an accelerometer, this will return the movement.

methods.description: If the device has a magnetometer, this will return the magnetic field strength in micro-Tesla for all axes.

methods.description: If the device has a gyroscope, this will return the rate of rotation in rad/s around a device's x, y, and z axis.

methods.description: Returns the mouse speed for the last time the cursor was moved, and this until the next frame where the mouse moves. This means that even if the mouse is not moving, this function will still return the value of the last motion.
methods.name: get_mouse_speed

methods.description: Returns mouse buttons as a bitmask. If multiple mouse buttons are pressed at the same time the bits are added together.

methods.description: Set the mouse mode. See the constants for more information.

methods.description:
Generally, files that are imported stay the same when exported. The only exception is in some cases when the file must be re-imported for different platforms (ie. texture compression).
				If you want to customize the export process, it's recommended to use [method EditorExportPlugin.custom_export] instead.
methods.name: custom_export

methods.description: Get the name of the import plugin, which will be used to identify content imported by this plugin. Try to use lowercase and underscores if possible.
methods.name: get_name

methods.description: Visible name for this plugin, which will be shown on the import menu.
methods.name: get_visible_name

methods.description:
Perform an import of an external resources into the project. This function is both called on import (from the dialog) or re-import (manual or automatic when external source files changed).
				An import process generally works like this:
				1) Check the metadata for source files and options. Metadata is either generated in the import dialog or taken from an existing resource upon reimport.
				2) Perform the import process into a new resource. Some times the resource being re-imported may be already loaded and in use, so checking for this by using [method ResourceLoader.has] is recommended. Otherwise create a new resource.
				3) Set the metadata from the argument into the existing or new resource being created using [method Resource.set_import_metadata].
				4) Save the resource into 'path' (function argument)
methods.name: import

methods.description:
This function is called when either the user chooses to import a resource of this type (Import menu), or when the user chooses to re-import the resource (from filesystem). In the later case, the path for the existing file is supplied in the argument.
				If the path is supplied, it is recommended to read the import metadata with [method ResourceLoader.load_import_metadata] and fill in the fields with the values contained there.
				The dialog can be shown in any way (just use a ConfirmationDialog and pop it up). Upon confirmation, fill up a ResourceImportMetadata and call the [method EditorImportPlugin.import] function with this information.
methods.name: import_dialog

EditorImportPlugin.description: Import plugins make it easy to handle importing of external assets into a project. They way they work is not that obvious though, so please make sure to read the documentation, tutorials and examples.
EditorImportPlugin.name: EditorImportPlugin

InputEventMouseMotion.brief_description: Built-in input event type for mouse motion events.

methods.description: Return if this input event matches a pre-defined action.

methods.description: Return whether the given action is being pressed. Not relevant for MOUSE_MOTION events, always false.

methods.description: Return whether the given action is released (i.e. not pressed). Not relevant for MOUSE_MOTION events, can be true or false depending on whether [method is_action] is true.

methods.description: Return if this input event is an echo event (only for events of type KEY, i.e. always false for this type).
methods.name: is_echo

methods.name: is_pressed

methods.name: set_as_action

Portal.brief_description: Portals provide virtual openings to rooms.

methods.description: Set the portal shape. The shape is an array of [Vector2] points, representing a convex polygon in the X,Y plane.
methods.name: set_shape

methods.description: Return the portal shape. The shape is an array of [Vector2] points, representing a convex polygon in the X,Y plane.
methods.name: get_shape

methods.description: Enable the portal (it is enabled by default though), disabling it will cause the parent [VisualInstance] to not be visible any longer when looking through the portal.
methods.name: set_enabled

methods.description: Return whether the portal is active. When disabled it causes the parent [VisualInstance] to not be visible any longer when looking through the portal.
methods.name: is_enabled

methods.description: Set the distance threshold for disabling the portal. Every time that the portal goes beyond "distance", it disables itself, becoming the opaque color (see [method set_disabled_color]).
methods.name: set_disable_distance

methods.description: Return the distance threshold for disabling the portal. Every time that the portal goes beyond "distance", it disables itself, becoming the opaque color (see [method set_disabled_color]).
methods.name: get_disable_distance

methods.description: When the portal goes beyond the disable distance (see [method set_disable_distance]), it becomes opaque and displayed with color "color".
methods.name: set_disabled_color

methods.description: Return the color for when the portal goes beyond the disable distance (see [method set_disable_distance]) and becomes disabled.
methods.name: get_disabled_color

methods.description: Set the range for auto-connecting two portals from different rooms sharing the same space.
methods.name: set_connect_range

methods.description: Return the range for auto-connecting two portals from different rooms sharing the same space.
methods.name: get_connect_range

Portal.description: Portals provide virtual openings to [VisualInstance] nodes, so cameras can look at them from the outside. Note that portals are a visibility optimization technique, and are in no way related to the game of the same name (as in, they are not used for teleportation). For more information on how rooms and portals work, see [VisualInstance]. Portals are represented as 2D convex polygon shapes (in the X,Y local plane), and are placed on the surface of the areas occupied by a [VisualInstance], to indicate that the room can be accessed or looked-at through them. If two rooms are next to each other, and two similar portals in each of them share the same world position (and are parallel and opposed to each other), they will automatically "connect" and form "doors" (for example, the portals that connect a kitchen to a living room are placed in the door they share). Portals must always have a [VisualInstance] node as a parent, grandparent or far parent, or else they will not be active.
Portal.name: Portal

ParallaxLayer.brief_description: A parallax scrolling layer to be used with [ParallaxBackground].

methods.description: Set the motion scale of the ParallaxLayer. If an axis is set to 0 then it will not move at all, it will stick with the camera.
methods.name: set_motion_scale

methods.description: Return the motion scale of the ParallaxLayer.
methods.name: get_motion_scale

methods.description: Set the mirroring of the ParallaxLayer. If an axis is set to 0 then that axis will have no mirroring.
methods.name: set_mirroring

methods.description: Return the mirroring of the ParallaxLayer.
methods.name: get_mirroring

ParallaxLayer.description: A ParallaxLayer must be the child of a [ParallaxBackground] node. All child nodes will be affected by the parallax scrolling of this layer.
ParallaxLayer.name: ParallaxLayer

GDFunctionState.brief_description: State of a function call after yielding.

methods.description:
Resume execution of the yielded function call.
				If handed an argument, return the argument from the [method @GDScript.yield] call in the yielded function call. You can pass e.g. an [Array] to hand multiple arguments.
				This function returns what the resumed function call returns, possibly another function state if yielded again.
methods.name: resume

methods.description: Check whether the function call may be resumed. This is not the case if the function state was already resumed.
methods.name: is_valid

GDFunctionState.description: Calling [method @GDScript.yield] within a function will cause that function to yield and return its current state as an object of this type. The yielded function call can then be resumed later by calling [method resume] on this state object.
GDFunctionState.name: GDFunctionState

ScrollContainer.brief_description: A helper node for displaying scrollable elements (e.g. lists).

methods.description: Set allows horizontal scroll.
methods.name: set_enable_h_scroll

methods.description: Return true if horizontal scroll is allowed.
methods.name: is_h_scroll_enabled

methods.description: Set allows vertical scroll.
methods.name: set_enable_v_scroll

methods.description: Return true if vertical scroll is allowed.
methods.name: is_v_scroll_enabled

methods.description: Set horizontal scroll value.
methods.name: set_h_scroll

methods.description: Return current horizontal scroll value.
methods.name: get_h_scroll

methods.description: Set vertical scroll value.
methods.name: set_v_scroll

methods.description: Return current vertical scroll value.
methods.name: get_v_scroll

ScrollContainer.description: A ScrollContainer node with a [Control] child and scrollbar child ([HScrollbar], [VScrollBar], or both) will only draw the Control within the ScrollContainer area.  Scrollbars will automatically be drawn at the right (for vertical) or bottom (for horizontal) and will enable dragging to move the viewable Control (and its children) within the ScrollContainer.  Scrollbars will also automatically resize the grabber based on the minimum_size of the Control relative to the ScrollContainer.  Works great with a [Panel] control.  You can set EXPAND on children size flags, so they will upscale to ScrollContainer size if ScrollContainer size is bigger (scroll is invisible for chosen dimension).
ScrollContainer.name: ScrollContainer

AudioServerSW.description:
This is a software audio server. It does not use any kind of hardware acceleration.
		This class does not expose any new method.
AudioServerSW.name: AudioServerSW

methods.description: Get the node name indicated by [code]idx[/code] (0 to [method get_name_count])
methods.name: get_name

methods.description: Get the number of node names which make up the path.
methods.name: get_name_count

methods.description: Get the path's property name, or an empty string if the path doesn't have a property.
methods.name: get_property

methods.description: Get the resource name indicated by [code]idx[/code] (0 to [method get_subname_count])
methods.name: get_subname

methods.description: Get the number of resource names in the path.
methods.name: get_subname_count

methods.description: Return true if the node path is absolute (not relative).
methods.name: is_absolute

methods.description: Return true if the node path is empty.
methods.name: is_empty

methods.description: Create a NodePath from a string, e.g. "Path2D/PathFollow2D/Sprite:texture:size". A path is absolute if it starts with a slash. Absolute paths are only valid in the global scene tree, not within individual scenes. In a relative path, [code]"."[/code] and [code]".."[/code] indicate the current node and its parent.
methods.name: NodePath

NodePath.description:
A pre-parsed relative or absolute path in a scene tree, for use with [method Node.get_node] and similar functions. It can reference a node, a resource within a node, or a property of a node or resource. For instance, [code]"Path2D/PathFollow2D/Sprite:texture:size"[/code] would refer to the size property of the texture resource on the node named "Sprite" which is a child of the other named nodes in the path. Note that if you want to get a resource, you must end the path with a colon, otherwise the last element will be used as a property name.
		You will usually just pass a string to [method Node.get_node] and it will be automatically converted, but you may occasionally want to parse a path ahead of time with [NodePath] or the literal syntax [code]@"path"[/code]. Exporting a [NodePath] variable will give you a node selection widget in the properties panel of the editor, which can often be useful.
		A [NodePath] is made up of a list of node names, a list of "subnode" (resource) names, and the name of a property in the final node or resource.
NodePath.name: NodePath

methods.description: Called during physics processing, allowing you to read and safely modify the simulation state for the object. By default it works in addition to the usual physics behavior, but [method set_use_custom_integrator] allows you to disable the default behavior and do fully custom force integration for a body.
methods.name: _integrate_forces

methods.description: Set the body mode, from the MODE_* enum. This allows to change to a static body or a character body.
methods.name: set_mode

methods.description: Return the current body mode, see [method set_mode].
methods.name: get_mode

methods.description: Set the body mass.
methods.name: set_mass

methods.description: Return the body mass.
methods.name: get_mass

methods.description: Return the body's moment of inertia. This is usually automatically computed from the mass and the shapes. Note that this doesn't seem to work in a [code]_ready[/code] function: it apparently has not been auto-computed yet.
methods.name: get_inertia

methods.description: Set the body's moment of inertia. This is like mass, but for rotation: it determines how much torque it takes to rotate the body. The moment of inertia is usually computed automatically from the mass and the shapes, but this function allows you to set a custom value. Set 0 (or negative) inertia to return to automatically computing it.
methods.name: set_inertia

methods.description: Set the body weight given standard earth-weight (gravity 9.8). Not really useful for 2D since most measures for this node are in pixels.
methods.name: set_weight

methods.description: Return the body weight given standard earth-weight (gravity 9.8).
methods.name: get_weight

methods.description: Set the body friction, from 0 (frictionless) to 1 (full friction).
methods.name: set_friction

methods.description: Return the body friction.
methods.name: get_friction

methods.description: Set the body bounciness, from 0 (no bounce) to 1 (full bounce).
methods.name: set_bounce

methods.description: Return the body bounciness.
methods.name: get_bounce

methods.description: Set the gravity factor. This factor multiplies gravity intensity just for this body.
methods.name: set_gravity_scale

methods.description: Return the gravity factor.
methods.name: get_gravity_scale

methods.description: Set the linear damp for this body. If this value is different from -1, any linear damp derived from the world or areas will be overridden.
methods.name: set_linear_damp

methods.description: Return the linear damp for this body.
methods.name: get_linear_damp

methods.description: Set the angular damp for this body. If this value is different from -1, any angular damp derived from the world or areas will be overridden.
methods.name: set_angular_damp

methods.description: Return the angular damp for this body.
methods.name: get_angular_damp

methods.description: Set the body linear velocity. Can be used sporadically, but [b]DON'T SET THIS IN EVERY FRAME[/b], because physics may be running in another thread and definitely runs at a different granularity. Use [method _integrate_forces] as your process loop if you want to have precise control of the body state.
methods.name: set_linear_velocity

methods.description: Return the body linear velocity. This changes by physics granularity. See [method set_linear_velocity].
methods.name: get_linear_velocity

methods.description: Set the body angular velocity. Can be used sporadically, but [b]DON'T SET THIS IN EVERY FRAME[/b], because physics may be running in another thread and definitely runs at a different granularity. Use [method _integrate_forces] as your process loop if you want to have precise control of the body state.
methods.name: set_angular_velocity

methods.description: Return the body angular velocity. This changes by physics granularity. See [method set_angular_velocity].
methods.name: get_angular_velocity

methods.description: Set the maximum contacts to report. Bodies can keep a log of the contacts with other bodies, this is enabled by setting the maximum amount of contacts reported to a number greater than 0.
methods.name: set_max_contacts_reported

methods.description: Return the maximum contacts that can be reported. See [method set_max_contacts_reported].
methods.name: get_max_contacts_reported

methods.description: Pass true to disable the internal force integration (like gravity or air friction) for this body. Other than collision response, the body will only move as determined by the [method _integrate_forces] function, if defined.
methods.name: set_use_custom_integrator

methods.description: Return true if the body is not doing any built-in force integration.
methods.name: is_using_custom_integrator

methods.description: Enable contact monitoring. This allows the body to emit signals when it collides with another.
methods.name: set_contact_monitor

methods.description: Return whether contact monitoring is enabled.
methods.name: is_contact_monitor_enabled

methods.description:
Set the continuous collision detection mode from the enum CCD_MODE_*.
				Continuous collision detection tries to predict where a moving body will collide, instead of moving it and correcting its movement if it collided. The first is more precise, and misses less impacts by small, fast-moving objects. The second is faster to compute, but can miss small, fast-moving objects.
methods.name: set_continuous_collision_detection_mode

methods.description: Return whether this body is using continuous collision detection.
methods.name: get_continuous_collision_detection_mode

methods.description: Set an axis velocity. The velocity in the given vector axis will be set as the given vector length. This is useful for jumping behavior.
methods.name: set_axis_velocity

methods.description: Apply a positioned impulse (which will be affected by the body mass and shape). This is the equivalent of hitting a billiard ball with a cue: a force that is applied once, and only once. Both the impulse and the offset from the body origin are in global coordinates.
methods.name: apply_impulse

methods.description: Set the applied force vector. This is the equivalent of pushing a box over the ground: the force applied is applied constantly.
methods.name: set_applied_force

methods.description: Return the applied force vector.
methods.name: get_applied_force

methods.description: Set a constant torque which will be applied to this body.
methods.name: set_applied_torque

methods.description: Return the torque which is being applied to this body.
methods.name: get_applied_torque

methods.description: Add a positioned force to the applied force and torque. As with [method apply_impulse], both the force and the offset from the body origin are in global coordinates.
methods.name: add_force

methods.description: Set whether a body is sleeping or not. Sleeping bodies are not affected by forces until a collision or an [method apply_impulse] / [method set_applied_force] wakes them up. Until then, they behave like a static body.
methods.name: set_sleeping

methods.description: Return whether the body is sleeping.
methods.name: is_sleeping

methods.description:
Set the body ability to fall asleep when not moving. This saves an enormous amount of processor time when there are plenty of rigid bodies (non static) in a scene.
				Sleeping bodies are not affected by forces until a collision or an [method apply_impulse] / [method set_applied_force] wakes them up. Until then, they behave like a static body.
methods.name: set_can_sleep

methods.description: Return true if the body has the ability to fall asleep when not moving. See [method set_can_sleep].
methods.name: is_able_to_sleep

methods.description: Return whether the body would collide, if it tried to move in the given vector. This method allows two extra parameters: A margin, which increases slightly the size of the shapes involved in the collision detection, and an object of type [Physics2DTestMotionResult], which will store additional information about the collision (should there be one).
methods.name: test_motion

methods.description: Return a list of the bodies colliding with this one. By default, number of max contacts reported is at 0 , see [method set_max_contacts_reported] to increase it. You must also enable contact monitor, see [method set_contact_monitor]
methods.name: get_colliding_bodies

RigidBody2D.description:
Rigid body 2D node. This node is used for placing rigid bodies in the scene. It can contain a number of shapes, and also shift state between regular Rigid body, Kinematic, Character or Static.
		Character mode forbids the node from being rotated. This node can have a custom force integrator function, for writing complex physics motion behavior per node.
		As a warning, don't change this node position every frame or very often. Sporadic changes work fine, but physics runs at a different granularity (fixed hz) than usual rendering (process callback) and maybe even in a separate thread, so changing this from a process loop will yield strange behavior.

constants.description: Static mode. The body behaves like a [StaticBody2D], and can only move by user code.
constants.name: MODE_STATIC

constants.description: Kinematic body. The body behaves like a [KinematicBody2D], and can only move by user code.
constants.name: MODE_KINEMATIC

constants.description: Rigid body. This is the "natural" state of a rigid body. It is affected by forces, and can move, rotate, and be affected by user code.
constants.name: MODE_RIGID

constants.description: Character body. This behaves like a rigid body, but can not rotate.
constants.name: MODE_CHARACTER

constants.description: Disables continuous collision detection. This is the fastest way to detect body collisions, but can miss small, fast-moving objects.
constants.name: CCD_MODE_DISABLED

constants.description: Enables continuous collision detection by raycasting. It is faster than shapecasting, but less precise.
constants.name: CCD_MODE_CAST_RAY

constants.description: Enables continuous collision detection by shapecasting. It is the slowest CCD method, and the most precise.
constants.name: CCD_MODE_CAST_SHAPE

RigidBody2D.name: RigidBody2D

signals.description: Emitted when a body enters into contact with this one. Contact monitor and contacts reported must be enabled for this to work.
signals.name: body_enter

signals.description:
Emitted when a body enters into contact with this one. Contact monitor and contacts reported must be enabled for this to work.
				This signal not only receives the body that collided with this one, but also its [RID] (body_id), the shape index from the colliding body (body_shape), and the shape index from this body (local_shape) the other body collided with.
signals.name: body_enter_shape

signals.description: Emitted when a body exits contact with this one. Contact monitor and contacts reported must be enabled for this to work.
signals.name: body_exit

signals.description:
Emitted when a body shape exits contact with this one. Contact monitor and contacts reported must be enabled for this to work.
				This signal not only receives the body that stopped colliding with this one, but also its [RID] (body_id), the shape index from the colliding body (body_shape), and the shape index from this body (local_shape) the other body stopped colliding with.
signals.name: body_exit_shape

signals.description: Emitted when the body changes it's sleeping state. Either by sleeping or waking up.
signals.name: sleeping_state_changed

methods.description:
Create a new [ImageTexture] with "width" and "height".

ImageTexture.description: A [Texture] based on an [Image]. Can be created from an [Image].

constants.description: [Image] data is stored raw and unaltered.
constants.name: STORAGE_RAW

constants.description: [Image] data is compressed with a lossy algorithm. You can set the storage quality with [method set_lossy_storage_quality].

constants.description: [Image] data is compressed with a lossless algorithm.

methods.description: Set the radius of the [CapsuleShape2D].
methods.name: set_radius

methods.description: Return the radius of the [CapsuleShape2D].

methods.description: Set the height of the [CapsuleShape2D].

methods.description: Return the height of the [CapsuleShape2D].

CapsuleShape2D.description: Capsule 2D shape resource for physics. A capsule (or sometimes called "pill") is like a line grown in all directions. It has a radius and a height, and is often useful for modeling biped characters.
CapsuleShape2D.name: CapsuleShape2D

methods.description: Set the total font height (ascent plus descent) in pixels.

OptionButton.brief_description: Button control that provides selectable options when pressed.

methods.description: Add an item, with text "label" and (optionally) id. If no "id" is passed, "id" becomes the item index. New items are appended at the end.

methods.description: Add an item, with a "texture" icon, text "label" and (optionally) id. If no "id" is passed, "id" becomes the item index. New items are appended at the end.

methods.description: Set the text of an item at index "idx".

methods.description: Set the icon of an item at index "idx".
methods.name: set_item_icon

methods.description: Set the ID of an item at index "idx".
methods.name: set_item_ID

methods.description: Return the text of the item at index "idx".
methods.name: get_item_text

methods.description: Return the icon of the item at index "idx".

methods.description: Return the ID of the item at index "idx".

signals.description: This signal is emitted when the current item was changed by the user. ID of the item selected is passed as argument (if no IDs were added, ID will be just the item index).
signals.name: item_selected

Directory.brief_description: Type used to handle the filesystem.

methods.description:
Open an existing directory of the filesystem. The [i]path[/i] argument can be within the project tree ([code]res://folder[/code]), the user directory ([code]user://folder[/code]) or an absolute path of the user filesystem (e.g. [code]/tmp/folder[/code] or [code]C:\tmp\folder[/code]).
				The method returns one of the error code constants defined in [@Global Scope] (OK or ERR_*).
methods.name: open

methods.description:
Initialise the stream used to list all files and directories using the [method get_next] function, closing the current opened stream if needed. Once the stream has been processed, it should typically be closed with [method list_dir_end].
				Return true if the stream could not be initialised.
methods.name: list_dir_begin

methods.description: Return the next element (file or directory) in the current directory (including [code].[/code] and [code]..[/code]). The name of the file or directory is returned (and not its full path). Once the stream has been fully processed, the method returns an empty String and closes the stream automatically (i.e. [method list_dir_end] would not be mandatory in such a case).
methods.name: get_next

methods.description: Return whether the current item processed with the last [method get_next] call is a directory ([code].[/code] and [code]..[/code] are considered directories).
methods.name: current_is_dir

methods.description: Close the current stream opened with [method list_dir_begin] (whether it has been fully processed with [method get_next] or not does not matter).
methods.name: list_dir_end

methods.description: On Windows, return the number of drives (partitions) mounted on the current filesystem. On other platforms, the method returns 0.
methods.name: get_drive_count

methods.description: On Windows, return the name of the drive (partition) passed as an argument (e.g. [code]C:[/code]). On other platforms, or if the requested drive does not existed, the method returns an empty String.
methods.name: get_drive

methods.description:
Change the currently opened directory to the one passed as an argument. The argument can be relative to the current directory (e.g. [code]newdir[/code] or [code]../newdir[/code]), or an absolute path (e.g. [code]/tmp/newdir[/code] or [code]res://somedir/newdir[/code]).
				The method returns one of the error code constants defined in [@Global Scope] (OK or ERR_*).
methods.name: change_dir

methods.description: Return the absolute path to the currently opened directory (e.g. [code]res://folder[/code] or [code]C:\tmp\folder[/code]).
methods.name: get_current_dir

methods.description:
Create a directory. The argument can be relative to the current directory, or an absolute path. The target directory should be placed in an already existing directory (to create the full path recursively, see [method make_dir_recursive]).
				The method returns one of the error code constants defined in [@Global Scope] (OK, FAILED or ERR_*).
methods.name: make_dir

methods.description:
Create a target directory and all necessary intermediate directories in its path, by calling [method make_dir] recursively. The argument can be relative to the current directory, or an absolute path.
				Return one of the error code constants defined in [@Global Scope] (OK, FAILED or ERR_*).
methods.name: make_dir_recursive

methods.description: Return whether the target file exists. The argument can be relative to the current directory, or an absolute path.

methods.description: Return whether the target directory exists. The argument can be relative to the current directory, or an absolute path.

methods.description: On Unix desktop systems, return the available space on the current directory's disk. On other platforms, this information is not available and the method returns 0 or -1.

methods.description:
Copy the [i]from[/i] file to the [i]to[/i] destination. Both arguments should be paths to files, either relative or absolute. If the destination file exists and is not access-protected, it will be overwritten.
				Returns one of the error code constants defined in [@Global Scope] (OK, FAILED or ERR_*).
methods.name: copy

methods.description:
Rename (move) the [i]from[/i] file to the [i]to[/i] destination. Both arguments should be paths to files, either relative or absolute. If the destination file exists and is not access-protected, it will be overwritten.
				Return one of the error code constants defined in [@Global Scope] (OK or FAILED).
methods.name: rename

methods.description:
Delete the target file or an empty directory. The argument can be relative to the current directory, or an absolute path. If the target directory is not empty, the operation will fail.

methods.description: Sets the distance from the first vertex, measured in pixels along the path. This sets this node's position to a point within the path.
methods.name: set_offset

methods.description: Returns the distance along the path in pixels.
methods.name: get_offset

methods.description:
Moves this node horizontally. As this node's position will be set every time its offset is set, this allows many PathFollow2D to share the same curve (and thus the same movement pattern), yet not return the same position for a given path offset.
				A similar effect may be achieved moving this node's descendants.
methods.name: set_h_offset

methods.description: Returns the horizontal displacement this node has from its parent [Path2D].
methods.name: get_h_offset

methods.description: Moves the PathFollow2D vertically, for the same reasons of [method set_h_offset].
methods.name: set_v_offset

methods.description: Returns the vertical displacement this node has from its parent [Path2D].
methods.name: get_v_offset

methods.description: Sets the distance from the first vertex, considering 0.0 as the first vertex and 1.0 as the last. This is just another way of expressing the offset within the path, as the offset supplied is multiplied internally by the path's length.
methods.name: set_unit_offset

methods.description: Returns the distance along the path as a number in the range 0.0 (for the first vertex) to 1.0 (for the last).
methods.name: get_unit_offset

methods.description: If set, this node rotates to follow the path, making its descendants rotate.
methods.name: set_rotate

methods.description: Returns whether this node rotates to follow the path.
methods.name: is_rotating

methods.description:
The points along the [Curve2D] of the [Path2D] are precomputed before use, for faster calculations. The point at the requested offset is then calculated interpolating between two adjacent cached points. This may present a problem if the curve makes sharp turns, as the cached points may not follow the curve closely enough.
				There are two answers to this problem: Either increase the number of cached points and increase memory consumption, or make a cubic interpolation between two points at the cost of (slightly) slower calculations.
				This method controls whether the position between two cached points is interpolated linearly, or cubicly.
methods.name: set_cubic_interpolation

methods.description: This method returns whether the position between two cached points (see [method set_cubic_interpolation]) is interpolated linearly, or cubicly.
methods.name: get_cubic_interpolation

methods.description: If set, any offset outside the path's length (whether set by [method set_offset] or [method set_unit_offset] will wrap around, instead of stopping at the ends. Set it for cyclic paths.
methods.name: set_loop

methods.description: Returns whether this node wraps its offsets around, or truncates them to the path ends.
methods.name: has_loop

PathFollow2D.description:
This node takes its parent [Path2D], and returns the coordinates of a point within it, given a distance from the first vertex.
		It is useful for making other nodes follow a path, without coding the movement pattern. For that, the nodes must be descendants of this node. Then, when setting an offset in this node, the descendant nodes will move accordingly.
PathFollow2D.name: PathFollow2D

ConfigFile.brief_description: Helper class to handle INI-style files.

methods.description: Assign a value to the specified key of the the specified section. If the section and/or the key do not exist, they are created. Passing a [code]NULL[/code] value deletes the specified key if it exists (and deletes the section if it ends up empty once the key has been removed).
methods.name: set_value

methods.description: Return the current value for the specified section and key. If the section and/or the key do not exist, the method returns the value of the optional [i]default[/i] argument (and thus [code]NULL[/code] if not specified).
methods.name: get_value

methods.description: Check if the specified section exists.
methods.name: has_section

methods.description: Check if the specified section-key pair exists.
methods.name: has_section_key

methods.description: Return an array of all defined section identifiers.
methods.name: get_sections

methods.description: Return an array of all defined key identifiers in the specified section.
methods.name: get_section_keys

methods.description: Load the config file specified as a parameter. The file's contents are parsed and loaded in the ConfigFile object from which the method was called. The return value is one of the OK, FAILED or ERR_* constants listed in [@Global Scope] (if the load was successful, it returns OK).
methods.name: load

methods.description:
Save the contents of the ConfigFile object to the file specified as a parameter. The output file uses an INI-style structure.
				The return value is one of the OK, FAILED or ERR_* constants listed in [@Global Scope] (if the save was successful, it returns OK).
methods.name: save

ConfigFile.description:
This helper class can be used to store [Variant] values on the filesystem using an INI-style formatting. The stored values as referenced by a section and a key. The stored data can be saved to or parsed from a file, though ConfigFile objects can also be used directly with accessing the filesystem.
		The following example shows how to parse a INI-style file from the system, read its contents and store new values in it:
		[codeblock]
		var config = ConfigFile.new()
		var err = config.load("user://settings.cfg")
		if err == OK: # if not, something went wrong with the file loading
		    # Look for the display/width pair, and default to 1024 if missing
		    var screen_width = get_value("display", "width", 1024)
		    # Store a variable if and only it hasn't been defined yet
		    if not config.has_section_key("audio", "mute"):
		        config.set_value("audio", "mute", false)
		    # Save the changes by overwriting the previous file
		    config.save("user://settings.cfg")
		[/codeblock]
ConfigFile.name: ConfigFile

StaticBody.description:
Static body for 3D Physics. A static body is a simple body that is not intended to move. They don't consume any CPU resources in contrast to a [RigidBody3D] so they are great for scenario collision.
		A static body can also be animated by using simulated motion mode. This is useful for implementing functionalities such as moving platforms. When this mode is active the body can be animated and automatically computes linear and angular velocity to apply in that frame and to influence other bodies.
		Alternatively, a constant linear or angular velocity can be set for the static body, so even if it doesn't move, it affects other bodies as if it was moving (this is useful for simulating conveyor belts or conveyor wheels).
StaticBody.name: StaticBody

Object.description:
Base class for all non built-in types. Everything not a built-in type starts the inheritance chain from this class.
		Objects do not manage memory, if inheriting from one the object will most likely have to be deleted manually (call the [method free] function from the script or delete from C++).
		Some derivates add memory management, such as [Reference] (which keeps a reference count and deletes itself automatically when no longer referenced) and [Node], which deletes the children tree when deleted.
		Objects export properties, which are mainly useful for storage and editing, but not really so much in programming. Properties are exported in [method _get_property_list] and handled in [method _get] and [method _set]. However, scripting languages and C++ have simpler means to export them.
		Objects also receive notifications ([method _notification]). Notifications are a simple way to notify the object about simple events, so they can all be handled together.

constants.description: Called right when the object is initialized. Not available in script.
constants.name: NOTIFICATION_POSTINITIALIZE

constants.description: Called before the object is about to be deleted.
constants.name: NOTIFICATION_PREDELETE

constants.description: Connect a signal in deferred mode. This way, signal emissions are stored in a queue, then set on idle time.
constants.name: CONNECT_DEFERRED

constants.description: Persisting connections are saved when the object is serialized to file.
constants.name: CONNECT_PERSIST

constants.description: One short connections disconnect themselves after emission.
constants.name: CONNECT_ONESHOT

GraphNode.description: A GraphNode is a container defined by a title. It can have 1 or more input and output slots, which can be enabled (shown) or disabled (not shown) and have different (incompatible) types. Colors can also be assigned to slots. A tuple of input and output slots is defined for each GUI element included in the GraphNode. Input and output connections are left and right slots, but only enabled slots are counted as connections.

EditorExportPlugin.brief_description: Editor plugin to control the export process.

methods.description:
This function is called for each file exported and depending from the return value one of many things might happen.
				1) If returned value is null, the file is exported as is.
				2) If the returned value is a RawAray (array of bytes), the content of that array becomes the new file being exported.
				3) If the file must also change it's name when exported, then a [Dictionary] must be returned with two fields: 'name' with the new filename and 'data' with a [RawArray] containing the raw contents of the file. Even if the name is changed, the run-time will redirect the old file to the new file automatically when accessed.
methods.name: custom_export

EditorExportPlugin.description: This plugin is added into EditorImportExport and allows to modify the behavior of the export process for individual files.
EditorExportPlugin.name: EditorExportPlugin

InstancePlaceholder.brief_description: Placeholder for the root [Node] of a [PackedScene].

methods.description: Replace this placeholder by the scene handed as an argument, or the original scene if no argument is given. As for all resources, the scene is loaded only if it's not loaded already. By manually loading the scene beforehand, delays caused by this function can be avoided.
methods.name: replace_by_instance

methods.description: Retrieve the path to the [PackedScene] resource file that is loaded by default when calling [method replace_by_instance].
methods.name: get_instance_path

InstancePlaceholder.description:
Turning on the option [b]Load As Placeholder[/b] for an instanced scene in the editor causes it to be replaced by an InstacePlaceholder when running the game. This makes it possible to delay actually loading the scene until calling [method replace_by_instance]. This is useful to avoid loading large scenes all at once by loading parts of it selectively.
		The InstancePlaceholder does not have a transform. This causes any child nodes to be positioned relatively to the Viewport from point (0,0), rather than their parent as displayed in the editor. Replacing the placeholder with a scene with a transform will transform children relatively to their parent again.
InstancePlaceholder.name: InstancePlaceholder

MultiMesh.description:
MultiMesh provides low level mesh instancing. If the amount of [Mesh] instances needed goes from hundreds to thousands (and most need to be visible at close proximity) creating such a large amount of [MeshInstance] nodes may affect performance by using too much CPU or video memory.
		For this case a MultiMesh becomes very useful, as it can draw thousands of instances with little API overhead.
		As a drawback, if the instances are too far away of each other, performance may be reduced as every single instance will always rendered (they are spatially indexed as one, for the whole object).
		Since instances may have any behavior, the AABB used for visibility must be provided by the user, or generated with [method generate_aabb].
MultiMesh.name: MultiMesh
