Curve3D.brief_description: Describes a Bezier curve in 3D space.

methods.description: Returns the number of points describing the curve.
methods.name: get_point_count

methods.description:
Adds a point to a curve, at position "pos", with control points "in" and "out".
				If "atpos" is given, the point is inserted before the point number "atpos", moving that point (and every point after) after the inserted point. If "atpos" is not given, or is an illegal value (atpos <0 or atpos >= [method get_point_count]), the point will be appended at the end of the point list.
methods.name: add_point

methods.description: Sets the position for the vertex "idx". If the index is out of bounds, the function sends an error to the console.
methods.name: set_point_pos

methods.description: Returns the position of the vertex "idx". If the index is out of bounds, the function sends an error to the console, and returns (0, 0, 0).
methods.name: get_point_pos

methods.description:
Sets the tilt angle in radians for the point "idx". If the index is out of bounds, the function sends an error to the console.
				The tilt controls the rotation along the look-at axis an object traveling the path would have. In the case of a curve controlling a [PathFollow], this tilt is an offset over the natural tilt the PathFollow calculates.
methods.name: set_point_tilt

methods.description: Returns the tilt angle in radians for the point "idx". If the index is out of bounds, the function sends an error to the console, and returns 0.
methods.name: get_point_tilt

methods.description: Sets the position of the control point leading to the vertex "idx". If the index is out of bounds, the function sends an error to the console.
methods.name: set_point_in

methods.description: Returns the position of the control point leading to the vertex "idx". If the index is out of bounds, the function sends an error to the console, and returns (0, 0, 0).
methods.name: get_point_in

methods.description: Sets the position of the control point leading out of the vertex "idx". If the index is out of bounds, the function sends an error to the console.
methods.name: set_point_out

methods.description: Returns the position of the control point leading out of the vertex "idx". If the index is out of bounds, the function sends an error to the console, and returns (0, 0, 0).
methods.name: get_point_out

methods.description: Deletes the point "idx" from the curve. Sends an error to the console if "idx" is out of bounds.
methods.name: remove_point

methods.description:
Returns the position between the vertex "idx" and the vertex "idx"+1, where "t" controls if the point is the first vertex (t = 0.0), the last vertex (t = 1.0), or in between. Values of "t" outside the range (0.0 >= t  <=1) give strange, but predictable results.
				If "idx" is out of bounds it is truncated to the first or last vertex, and "t" is ignored. If the curve has no points, the function sends an error to the console, and returns (0, 0, 0).
methods.name: interpolate

methods.description: Returns the position at the vertex "fofs". It calls [method interpolate] using the integer part of fofs as "idx", and its fractional part as "t".
methods.name: interpolatef

methods.description: Sets the distance in 3D units between two adjacent cached points. Changing it forces the cache to be recomputed the next time a xxx_baked_xxx function is called. The less distance, the more points the cache will have, and the more memory it will consume, so use with care.
methods.name: set_bake_interval

methods.description: Returns the distance between two adjacent cached points.
methods.name: get_bake_interval

methods.description: Returns the total length of the curve, based on the cached points. Given enough density (see [method set_bake_interval]), it should be approximate enough.
methods.name: get_baked_length

methods.description:
Returns a point within the curve at position "offset", where "offset" is measured as a distance in 3D units along the curve.
				To do that, it finds the two cached points where the "offset" lies between, then interpolates the values. This interpolation is cubic if "cubic" is set to true, or linear if set to false.
				Cubic interpolation tends to follow the curves better, but linear is faster (and often, precise enough).
methods.name: interpolate_baked

methods.description: Returns the cache of points as a [Vector3Array].
methods.name: get_baked_points

methods.description: Returns the cache of tilts as a [RealArray].
methods.name: get_baked_tilts

methods.description:
Returns a list of points along the curve, with a curvature controlled point density. That is, the curvier parts will have more points than the straighter parts.
				This approximation makes straight segments between each point, then subdivides those segments until the resulting shape is similar enough.
				"max_stages" controls how many subdivisions a curve segment may face before it is considered approximate enough. Each subdivision splits the segment in half, so the default 5 stages may mean up to 32 subdivisions per curve segment. Increase with care!
				"tolerance_degrees" controls how many degrees the midpoint of a segment may deviate from the real curve, before the segment has to be subdivided.
methods.name: tesselate

Curve3D.description:
This class describes a Bezier curve in 3D space. It is mainly used to give a shape to a [Path], but can be manually sampled for other purposes.
		It keeps a cache of precalculated points along the curve, to speed further calculations up.
Curve3D.name: Curve3D

EditorScript.brief_description: Simple script to perform changes in the currently edited scene.
EditorScript.description: This script can be run from the Scene -> Run Script menu option.
EditorScript.name: EditorScript

methods.description: Called during physics processing, allowing you to read and safely modify the simulation state for the object. By default it works in addition to the usual physics behavior, but [method set_use_custom_integrator] allows you to disable the default behavior and do fully custom force integration for a body.
methods.name: _integrate_forces

methods.description: Set the body mode, from the MODE_* enum. This allows to change to a static body or a character body.
methods.name: set_mode

methods.description: Return the current body mode, see [method set_mode].
methods.name: get_mode

methods.description: Set the body mass.
methods.name: set_mass

methods.description: Return the current body mass.
methods.name: get_mass

methods.description: Set the body weight given standard earth-weight (gravity 9.8).
methods.name: set_weight

methods.description: Return the current body weight, given standard earth-weight (gravity 9.8).
methods.name: get_weight

methods.description: Set the body friction, from 0 (frictionless) to 1 (max friction).
methods.name: set_friction

methods.description: Return the current body friction, from 0 (frictionless) to 1 (max friction).
methods.name: get_friction

methods.description: Set the body bounciness, from 0 (no bounciness) to 1 (max bounciness).
methods.name: set_bounce

methods.description: Return the current body bounciness.
methods.name: get_bounce

methods.description: Set the body linear velocity. Can be used sporadically, but [b]DON'T SET THIS IN EVERY FRAME[/b], because physics may be running in another thread and definitely runs at a different granularity. Use [method _integrate_forces] as your process loop if you want to have precise control of the body state.
methods.name: set_linear_velocity

methods.description: Return the current body linear velocity.
methods.name: get_linear_velocity

methods.description: Set the body angular velocity. Can be used sporadically, but [b]DON'T SET THIS IN EVERY FRAME[/b], because physics may be running in another thread and definitely runs at a different granularity. Use [method _integrate_forces] as your process loop if you want to have precise control of the body state.
methods.name: set_angular_velocity

methods.description: Return the current body angular velocity.
methods.name: get_angular_velocity

methods.description: Set the gravity factor. This factor multiplies gravity intensity just for this body.
methods.name: set_gravity_scale

methods.description: Return the current body gravity scale.
methods.name: get_gravity_scale

methods.description: Set the linear damp for this body. Default of -1, cannot be less than -1. If this value is different from -1, any linear damp derived from the world or areas will be overridden.
methods.name: set_linear_damp

methods.description: Return the current body linear damp. Default is -1.
methods.name: get_linear_damp

methods.description: Set the angular damp for this body. Default of -1, cannot be less than -1. If this value is different from -1, any angular damp derived from the world or areas will be overridden.
methods.name: set_angular_damp

methods.description: Return the current body angular damp. Default is -1.
methods.name: get_angular_damp

methods.description: Set the maximum contacts to report. Bodies can keep a log of the contacts with other bodies, this is enabled by setting the maximum amount of contacts reported to a number greater than 0.
methods.name: set_max_contacts_reported

methods.description: Return the maximum contacts that can be reported. See [method set_max_contacts_reported].
methods.name: get_max_contacts_reported

methods.description: Pass true to disable the internal force integration (like gravity or air friction) for this body. Other than collision response, the body will only move as determined by the [method _integrate_forces] function, if defined.
methods.name: set_use_custom_integrator

methods.description: Return whether the body is using a custom integrator.
methods.name: is_using_custom_integrator

methods.description: Enable contact monitoring. This allows the body to emit signals when it collides with another.
methods.name: set_contact_monitor

methods.description: Return whether contact monitoring is enabled.
methods.name: is_contact_monitor_enabled

methods.description:
Set the continuous collision detection mode from the enum CCD_MODE_*.
				Continuous collision detection tries to predict where a moving body will collide, instead of moving it and correcting its movement if it collided. The first is more precise, and misses less impacts by small, fast-moving objects. The second is faster to compute, but can miss small, fast-moving objects.
methods.name: set_use_continuous_collision_detection

methods.description: Return whether this body is using continuous collision detection.
methods.name: is_using_continuous_collision_detection

methods.description: Set an axis velocity. The velocity in the given vector axis will be set as the given vector length. This is useful for jumping behavior.
methods.name: set_axis_velocity

methods.description: Apply a positioned impulse (which will be affected by the body mass and shape). This is the equivalent of hitting a billiard ball with a cue: a force that is applied once, and only once. Both the impulse and the offset from the body origin are in global coordinates.
methods.name: apply_impulse

methods.description: Set whether a body is sleeping or not. Sleeping bodies are not affected by forces until a collision or an [method apply_impulse] wakes them up. Until then, they behave like a static body.
methods.name: set_sleeping

methods.description: Return whether the body is sleeping.
methods.name: is_sleeping

methods.description:
Set the body ability to fall asleep when not moving. This saves an enormous amount of processor time when there are plenty of rigid bodies (non static) in a scene.
				Sleeping bodies are not affected by forces until a collision or an [method apply_impulse] / [method set_applied_force] wakes them up. Until then, they behave like a static body.
methods.name: set_can_sleep

methods.description: Return whether the body has the ability to fall asleep when not moving. See [method set_can_sleep].
methods.name: is_able_to_sleep

methods.description: Set the axis lock of the body, from the AXIS_LOCK_* enum. Axis lock stops the body from moving along the specified axis(X/Y/Z) and rotating along the other two axes.
methods.name: set_axis_lock

methods.description: Return the current axis lock of the body. One of AXIS_LOCK_* enum.
methods.name: get_axis_lock

methods.description: Return a list of the bodies colliding with this one. By default, number of max contacts reported is at 0 , see [method set_max_contacts_reported] to increase it.
methods.name: get_colliding_bodies

RigidBody.description: Rigid body node. This node is used for placing rigid bodies in the scene. It can contain a number of shapes, and also shift mode between regular Rigid body, Kinematic, Character or Static.

constants.description: Static mode. The body behaves like a [StaticBody], and can only move by user code.
constants.name: MODE_STATIC

constants.description: Kinematic body. The body behaves like a [KinematicBody], and can only move by user code.
constants.name: MODE_KINEMATIC

constants.description: Rigid body. This is the "natural" state of a rigid body. It is affected by forces, and can move, rotate, and be affected by user code.
constants.name: MODE_RIGID

constants.description: Character body. This behaves like a rigid body, but can not rotate.
constants.name: MODE_CHARACTER

RigidBody.name: RigidBody

signals.description: Emitted when a body enters into contact with this one. Contact monitor and contacts reported must be enabled for this to work.
signals.name: body_enter

signals.description:
Emitted when a body enters into contact with this one. Contact monitor and contacts reported must be enabled for this to work.
				This signal not only receives the body that collided with this one, but also its [RID] (body_id), the shape index from the colliding body (body_shape), and the shape index from this body (local_shape) the other body collided with.
signals.name: body_enter_shape

signals.description: Emitted when a body shape exits contact with this one. Contact monitor and contacts reported must be enabled for this to work.
signals.name: body_exit

signals.description:
Emitted when a body shape exits contact with this one. Contact monitor and contacts reported must be enabled for this to work.
				This signal not only receives the body that stopped colliding with this one, but also its [RID] (body_id), the shape index from the colliding body (body_shape), and the shape index from this body (local_shape) the other body stopped colliding with.
signals.name: body_exit_shape

signals.description: Emitted when the body changes it's sleeping state. Either by sleeping or waking up.
signals.name: sleeping_state_changed

AnimationTreePlayer.brief_description: Animation Player that uses a node graph for the blending.

methods.description: Add a node of a given type in the graph with given id.
methods.name: add_node

methods.description: Check if a node exists (by name).
methods.name: node_exists

methods.description: Rename a node in the graph.
methods.name: node_rename

methods.description: Get the node type, will return from NODE_* enum.
methods.name: node_get_type

methods.description: Return the input count for a given node. Different types of nodes have different amount of inputs.
methods.name: node_get_input_count

methods.description: Return the input source for a given node input.
methods.name: node_get_input_source

methods.description: Set the animation for an animation node.
methods.name: animation_node_set_animation

AnimationTreePlayer.description: Animation Player that uses a node graph for the blending. This kind of player is very useful when animating character or other skeleton based rigs, because it can combine several animations to form a desired pose.
AnimationTreePlayer.name: AnimationTreePlayer

methods.description: If this is set to true then the particle emitter will emit particles, if its false it will not.
methods.name: set_emitting

methods.description: Returns whether this emitter is currently emitting or not
methods.name: is_emitting

methods.description: Sets the amount of particles spawned at each emission
methods.name: set_amount

methods.description: Returns the amount of particles spawned at each emission
methods.name: get_amount

methods.description: Sets the amount of seconds that each particle will be visible.
methods.name: set_lifetime

methods.description: Gets the amount of seconds that each particle will be visible.
methods.name: get_lifetime

methods.description: Sets the increment or decrement for the particle lifetime. for example: if the time scale is set to 2, the particles will die and move twice as fast.
methods.name: set_time_scale

methods.description: Returns the emitter time scale
methods.name: get_time_scale

methods.description: Sets the amount of seconds during which the emitter will spawn particles, after the specified seconds the emitter state will be set to non emitting, so calling [method is_emitting] will return false. If the timeout is 0 the emitter will spawn forever.
methods.name: set_emit_timeout

methods.description: Returns the amount of seconds during which the emitter will spawn particles
methods.name: get_emit_timeout

methods.description: Sets the value of the specified emitter parameter (see the constants secction for the list of parameters)
methods.name: set_param

methods.description: Returns the value of the specified emitter parameter
methods.name: get_param

methods.description: Sets the randomness value of the specified emitter parameter (see the constants secction for the list of parameters), 0 means no randomness, so every particle will have the parameters specified, 1 means that the parameter will be choosen at random, the closer the randomness value gets to 0 the more conservative the variation of the parameter will be.
methods.name: set_randomness

methods.description: Returns the randomness value of the specified emitter parameter
methods.name: get_randomness

methods.description: Sets the texture for each particle
methods.name: set_texture

methods.description: Returns the texture for emitted particles
methods.name: get_texture

methods.description: Set the tint color for each particle.
methods.name: set_color

methods.description: Returns the tint color for each particle.
methods.name: get_color

methods.description: Sets the [ColorRamp] used to tint each particle. Particle will be tinted according to their lifetimes.
methods.name: set_color_ramp

methods.description: Returns the [ColorRamp] used to tint each particle
methods.name: get_color_ramp

methods.description: Sets the particle spawn origin position relative to the emitter center. for example if this value is set to (50, 50), the particle will spawn 50 units to the right and  50 units to the bottom of the emitter center.
methods.name: set_emissor_offset

methods.description: Returns the particle spawn origin position relative to the emitter.
methods.name: get_emissor_offset

methods.description: Sets the half extents of the emission box, particles will be spawned at random inside this box.
methods.name: set_emission_half_extents

methods.description: Returns the half extents of the emission box.
methods.name: get_emission_half_extents

Particles2D.description: Particles2D is a particle system 2D [Node] that is used to simulate several types of particle effects, such as explosions, rain, snow, fireflies, or other magical-like shinny sparkles. Particles are drawn using impostors, and given their dynamic behavior, the user must provide a visibility AABB (although helpers to create one automatically exist).

constants.description: Direction in degrees at which the particles will be launched, Notice that when the direction is set to 0 the particles will be launched to the negative
constants.name: PARAM_DIRECTION

constants.description: Velocity at which the particles will be launched.
constants.name: PARAM_LINEAR_VELOCITY

constants.description: The speed at which particles will spin around its own center.
constants.name: PARAM_SPIN_VELOCITY

constants.description: Velocity at which the particles will orbit around the emitter center
constants.name: PARAM_ORBIT_VELOCITY

constants.description: Direction in degrees at which the particles will be attracted
constants.name: PARAM_GRAVITY_DIRECTION

constants.description: Strength of the gravitation attraction for each particle
constants.name: PARAM_GRAVITY_STRENGTH

constants.description: Amount of damping for each particle
constants.name: PARAM_DAMPING

constants.description: Initial angle in radians at which each particle will be spawned
constants.name: PARAM_INITIAL_ANGLE

constants.description: Final size of each particle, the particle size will interpolate to this value during its lifetime.
constants.name: PARAM_FINAL_SIZE

Particles2D.name: Particles2D

methods.description: Return the loaded resource (only if loaded). Otherwise, returns null.
methods.name: get_resource

methods.description: Poll the load. If OK is returned, this means poll will have to be called again. If ERR_EOF is returned, them the load has finished and the resource can be obtained by calling [method get_resource].
methods.name: poll

methods.description: Return the load stage. The total amount of stages can be queried with [method get_stage_count]
methods.name: get_stage

methods.description: Return the total amount of stages (calls to [method poll]) needed to completely load this resource.
methods.name: get_stage_count

ResourceInteractiveLoader.description: Interactive Resource Loader. This object is returned by ResourceLoader when performing an interactive load. It allows to load with high granularity, so this is mainly useful for displaying load bars/percentages.
ResourceInteractiveLoader.name: ResourceInteractiveLoader

VisibilityNotifier2D.brief_description: Detect when the node is visible on screen.

methods.description: Set the visibility bounding rectangle of the VisibilityNotifier2D.
methods.name: set_rect

methods.description: Return the visibility bounding rectangle of the VisibilityNotifier2D.
methods.name: get_rect

methods.description: Return true if any part of the bounding rectangle is on the screen.
methods.name: is_on_screen

VisibilityNotifier2D.description: The VisibilityNotifier2D is used to notify when its bounding rectangle enters the screen, is visible on the screen, or when it exits the screen.
VisibilityNotifier2D.name: VisibilityNotifier2D

signals.description: Emitted when the VisibilityNotifier2D enters the screen.

signals.description: Emitted when the VisibilityNotifier2D enters a [Viewport].

signals.description: Emitted when the VisibilityNotifier2D exits the screen.

SpotLight.brief_description: Spotlight [Light], such as a reflector spotlight or a lantern.
SpotLight.description: A SpotLight light is a type of [Light] node that emits lights in a specific direction, in the shape of a cone. The light is attenuated through the distance and this attenuation can be configured by changing the energy, radius and attenuation parameters of [Light]. TODO: Image of a spotlight.
SpotLight.name: SpotLight

methods.description: Define the set of vertices that will represent the polygon.
methods.name: set_polygon

methods.description: Return the set of vertices that defines this polygon.
methods.name: get_polygon

methods.description: Set the texture coordinates for every vertex of the polygon. There should be one uv vertex for every vertex in the polygon. If there are less, the undefined ones will be assumed to be (0,0). Extra uv vertices are ignored.
methods.name: set_uv

methods.description: Return the texture coordinates associated with every vertex of the polygon.
methods.name: get_uv

methods.description: Set the polygon fill color. If the polygon has a texture defined, the defined texture will be multiplied by the polygon fill color. This, also, is the default color for those vertices that are not defined by [method get_vertex_colors].
methods.name: set_color

methods.description: Return the polygon fill color.
methods.name: get_color

methods.description:
Set the color for each vertex of the polygon. There should be one color for every vertex in the polygon. If there are less, the undefined ones will be assumed to be [method get_color]. Extra color entries are ignored.
	Colors are interpolated between vertices, resulting in smooth gradients when they differ.
methods.name: set_vertex_colors

methods.description: Return the list of vertex colors.
methods.name: get_vertex_colors

methods.description: Set the polygon texture.
methods.name: set_texture

methods.description: Return the polygon texture
methods.name: get_texture

methods.description: Set the offset of the polygon texture. Initially the texture will appear anchored to the polygon position, the offset is used to move the texture location away from that point (notice that the texture origin is set to its top left corner, so when offset is 0,0 the top left corner of the texture is at the polygon position), for example setting the offset to 10, 10 will move the texture 10 units to the left and 10 units to the top.
methods.name: set_texture_offset

methods.description: Return the polygon texture offset.
methods.name: get_texture_offset

methods.description: Set the amount of rotation of the polygon texture, [code]texture_rotation[/code] is specified in radians and clockwise rotation.
methods.name: set_texture_rotation

methods.description: Return the rotation in radians of the texture polygon.
methods.name: get_texture_rotation

methods.description: Set the value that will multiply the uv coordinates ([method get_uv]) when applying the texture. Larger values make the texture smaller, and vice versa.
methods.name: set_texture_scale

methods.description: Return the uv coordinate multiplier.
methods.name: get_texture_scale

methods.description: Set the polygon as the defined polygon bounding box minus the defined polygon (the defined polygon will appear as a hole on the square that contains the defined polygon).
methods.name: set_invert

methods.description: Return whether this polygon is inverted or not.
methods.name: get_invert

methods.description: Add extra padding around the bounding box, making it bigger. Too small a value can make the polygon triangulate strangely, due to numerical imprecision.
methods.name: set_invert_border

methods.description: Return the added padding around the bounding box.
methods.name: get_invert_border

methods.description: Set the an offset that will be added to the vertices' position. E.g. if the offset is set to (10,10) then all the polygon points will move 10 units to the right and 10 units to the bottom.
methods.name: set_offset

methods.description: Return the offset for the polygon vertices.
methods.name: get_offset

Polygon2D.description: A Polygon2D is defined by a set of n vertices connected together by line segments, meaning that the vertex 1 will be connected with vertex 2, vertex 2 with vertex 3 ..., vertex n-1 with vertex n and vertex n with vertex 1 in order to close the loop and define a polygon.
Polygon2D.name: Polygon2D

methods.description: Return the capsule radius.
methods.name: get_radius

methods.description: Set the capsule height.
methods.name: set_height

methods.description: Return the capsule height.
methods.name: get_height

CapsuleShape.description: Capsule shape resource, which can be set into a [PhysicsBody] or area.
CapsuleShape.name: CapsuleShape

methods.description: Set the peer object to handle the RPC system (effectively enabling networking). Depending on the peer itself, the SceneTree will become a network server (check with [method is_network_server()]) and will set root node's network mode to master (see NETWORK_MODE_* constants in [Node]), or it will become a regular peer with root node set to slave. All child nodes are set to inherit the network mode by default. Handling of networking-related events (connection, disconnection, new clients) is done by connecting to SceneTree's signals.

methods.description:

				Sends body raw, as a byte array, does not encode it in any way.

methods.description: Sets the distance from the first vertex, measured in 3D units along the path. This sets this node's position to a point within the path.

methods.name: get_offset

methods.description:
Moves this node in the X axis. As this node's position will be set every time its offset is set, this allows many PathFollow to share the same curve (and thus the same movement pattern), yet not return the same position for a given path offset.
				A similar effect may be achieved moving the this node's descendants.
methods.name: set_h_offset

methods.description: Returns the X displacement this node has from its parent [Path].
methods.name: get_h_offset

methods.description: Moves this node in the Y axis, for the same reasons of [method set_h_offset].
methods.name: set_v_offset

methods.description: Returns the Y displacement this node has from its parent [Path].
methods.name: get_v_offset

methods.description: Sets the distance from the first vertex, considering 0.0 as the first vertex and 1.0 as the last. This is just another way of expressing the offset within the path, as the offset supplied is multiplied internally by the path's length.
methods.name: set_unit_offset

methods.description: Returns the distance along the path as a number in the range 0.0 (for the first vertex) to 1.0 (for the last).
methods.name: get_unit_offset

methods.description: Allows or forbids rotation on one or more axes, per the constants below.
methods.name: set_rotation_mode

methods.description: Returns the rotation mode. The constants below list which axes are allowed to rotate for each mode.
methods.name: get_rotation_mode

methods.description:
The points along the [Curve3D] of the [Path] are precomputed before use, for faster calculations. The point at the requested offset is then calculated interpolating between two adjacent cached points. This may present a problem if the curve makes sharp turns, as the cached points may not follow the curve closely enough.
				There are two answers to this problem: Either increase the number of cached points and increase memory consumption, or make a cubic interpolation between two points at the cost of (slightly) slower calculations.
				This method controls whether the position between two cached points is interpolated linearly, or cubicly.
methods.name: set_cubic_interpolation

methods.description: This method returns whether the position between two cached points (see [method set_cubic_interpolation]) is interpolated linearly, or cubicly.
methods.name: get_cubic_interpolation

methods.description: If set, any offset outside the path's length (whether set by [method set_offset] or [method set_unit_offset] will wrap around, instead of stopping at the ends. Set it for cyclic paths.
methods.name: set_loop

methods.description: Returns whether this node wraps its offsets around, or truncates them to the path ends.
methods.name: has_loop

PathFollow.description:
This node takes its parent [Path], and returns the coordinates of a point within it, given a distance from the first vertex.
		It is useful for making other nodes follow a path, without coding the movement pattern. For that, the nodes must be descendants of this node. Then, when setting an offset in this node, the descendant nodes will move accordingly.

constants.description: Allows the PathFollow to rotate in the Y axis only.
constants.name: ROTATION_Y

constants.description: Allows the PathFollow to rotate in both the X, and Y axes.
constants.name: ROTATION_XY

constants.description: Allows the PathFollow to rotate in any axis.
constants.name: ROTATION_XYZ

PathFollow.name: PathFollow

methods.description:
Create new data for the sample, with format (see FORMAT_* constants), stereo hint, and length in samples (not bytes).
				Calling this method overrides previously existing data. Stereo samples are interleaved pairs of left and right points (in that order), but count as one sample for length purposes.
methods.name: create

methods.description: Return the sample format.
methods.name: get_format

methods.description: Return whether the current sample was created as stereo.
methods.name: is_stereo

methods.description: Return the sample length in samples. Stereo samples count as one, even if they are made of a left and a right sample.
methods.name: get_length

methods.description:
Set sample data. Data must be little endian, no matter the host platform, and exactly as long as to fit all samples. The length of this array can be calculated as follows:
				Get the sample length ([method get_length]). If the sample format is FORMAT_PCM16, multiply it by 2. If the sample format is FORMAT_IMA_ADPCM, divide it by 2 (rounding any fraction up), then add 4. If the sample is stereo ([method is_stereo]), multiply it by 2.
methods.name: set_data

methods.description: Return sample data as little endian.
methods.name: get_data

methods.description: Set the loop end position. It must be a valid frame and greater than the loop begin position.
methods.name: set_loop_end

ConvexPolygonShape2D.description:
Convex Polygon Shape for 2D physics. A convex polygon, whatever its shape, is internally decomposed into as many convex polygons as needed to ensure all collision checks against it are always done on convex polygons (which are faster to check).
		The main difference between a [ConvexPolygonShape2D] and a [ConcavePolygonShape2D] is that a concave polygon assumes it is concave and uses a more complex method of collision detection, and a convex one forces itself to be convex in order to speed up collision detection.
ConvexPolygonShape2D.name: ConvexPolygonShape2D

methods.description: Returns the time needed for all tweens to end in seconds, measured from the start. Thus, if you have two tweens, one ending 10 seconds after the start and the other - 20 seconds, it would return 20 seconds, as by that time all tweens would have finished.
methods.name: get_runtime

methods.description:
Animate [code]property[/code] of [code]object[/code] from [code]initial_val[/code] to [code]final_val[/code] for [code]times_in_sec[/code] seconds, [code]delay[/code] seconds later.
				[code]trans_type[/code] accepts TRANS_* constants, and is the way the animation is interpolated, while [code]ease_type[/code] accepts EASE_* constants, and controls the place of the interpolation (the begining, the end, or both). You can read more about them in the class description.
methods.name: interpolate_property

methods.description:
Animate [code]method[/code] of [code]object[/code] from [code]initial_val[/code] to [code]final_val[/code] for [code]times_in_sec[/code] seconds, [code]delay[/code] seconds later. Methods are animated by calling them with consecuitive values.
				[code]trans_type[/code] accepts TRANS_* constants, and is the way the animation is interpolated, while [code]ease_type[/code] accepts EASE_* constants, and controls the place of the interpolation (the begining, the end, or both). You can read more about them in the class description.
methods.name: interpolate_method

methods.description: Call [code]callback[/code] of [code]object[/code] after [code]times_in_sec[/code]. [code]arg1[/code]-[code]arg5[/code] are arguments to be passed to the callback.
methods.name: interpolate_callback

methods.description: Call [code]callback[/code] of [code]object[/code] after [code]times_in_sec[/code] on the main thread (similar to [methog Object.call_deferred). [code]arg1[/code]-[code]arg5[/code] are arguments to be passed to the callback.
methods.name: interpolate_deferred_callback

methods.description:
Follow [code]property[/code] of [code]object[/code] and apply it on [code]target_property[/code] of [code]target[/code], beginning from [code]initial_val[/code] for [code]times_in_sec[/code] seconds, [code]delay[/code] seconds later. Note that [code]target:target_property[/code] would equal [code]object:property[/code] at the end of the tween.
				[code]trans_type[/code] accepts TRANS_* constants, and is the way the animation is interpolated, while [code]ease_type[/code] accepts EASE_* constants, and controls the place of the interpolation (the begining, the end, or both). You can read more about them in the class description.
methods.name: follow_property

methods.description:
Follow [code]method[/code] of [code]object[/code] and apply the returned value on [code]target_method[/code] of [code]target[/code], beginning from [code]initial_val[/code] for [code]times_in_sec[/code] seconds, [code]delay[/code] later. Methods are animated by calling them with consequitive values.
				[code]trans_type[/code] accepts TRANS_* constants, and is the way the animation is interpolated, while [code]ease_type[/code] accepts EASE_* constants, and controls the place of the interpolation (the begining, the end, or both). You can read more about them in the class description.
methods.name: follow_method

methods.description:
Animate [code]property[/code] of [code]object[/code] from the current value of the [code]initial_val[/code] property of [code]initial[/code] to [code]final_val[/code] for [code]times_in_sec[/code] seconds, [code]delay[/code] seconds later.
				[code]trans_type[/code] accepts TRANS_* constants, and is the way the animation is interpolated, while [code]ease_type[/code] accepts EASE_* constants, and controls the place of the interpolation (the begining, the end, or both). You can read more about them in the class description.
methods.name: targeting_property

methods.description:
Animate [code]method[/code] of [code]object[/code] from the value returned by [code]initial.initial_method[/code] to [code]final_val[/code] for [code]times_in_sec[/code] seconds, [code]delay[/code] seconds later. Methods are animated by calling them with consecuitive values.
				[code]trans_type[/code] accepts TRANS_* constants, and is the way the animation is interpolated, while [code]ease_type[/code] accepts EASE_* constants, and controls the place of the interpolation (the begining, the end, or both). You can read more about them in the class description.
methods.name: targeting_method

Tween.description:
Node useful for animations with unknown start and end points, procedural animations, making one node follow another, and other simple behavior.
		Because it is easy to get it wrong, here is a quick usage example:
		[codeblock]
		var tween = get_node("Tween")
		tween.interpolate_property(get_node("Node2D_to_move"), "transform/pos", Vector2(0,0), Vector2(100,100), 1, Tween.TRANS_LINEAR, Tween.EASE_IN_OUT)
		tween.start()
		[/codeblock]
		Some of the methods of this class require a property name. You can get the property name by hovering over the property in the inspector of the editor.
		Many of the methods accept [code]trans_type[/code] and [code]ease_type[/code]. The first accepts an TRANS_* constant, and refers to the way the timing of the animation is handled (you might want to see [code]http://easings.net/[/code] for some examples). The second accepts an EASE_* constant, and controls the where [code]trans_type[/code] is applied to the interpolation (in the begining, the end, or both). If you don't know which transision and easing to pick, you can try different TRANS_* constants with EASE_IN_OUT, and use the one that looks best.

constants.description: The [Tween] should use [code]_fixed_process[/code] for timekeeping when this is enabled.
constants.name: TWEEN_PROCESS_FIXED

constants.description: The [Tween] should use [code]_process[/code] for timekeeping when this is enabled (default).
constants.name: TWEEN_PROCESS_IDLE

constants.description: Means that the animation is interpolated linearly.
constants.name: TRANS_LINEAR

constants.description: Means that the animation is interpolated using a sine wave.
constants.name: TRANS_SINE

constants.description: Means that the animation is interpolated with a quinary (to the power of 5) function.
constants.name: TRANS_QUINT

constants.description: Means that the animation is interpolated with a quartic (to the power of 4) function.
constants.name: TRANS_QUART

constants.description: Means that the animation is interpolated with a quadratic (to the power of 2) function.
constants.name: TRANS_QUAD

constants.description: Means that the animation is interpolated with a exponential (some number to the power of x) function.
constants.name: TRANS_EXPO

constants.description: Means that the animation is interpolated with elasticity, wiggling around the edges.
constants.name: TRANS_ELASTIC

constants.description: Means that the animation is interpolated with a cubic (to the power of 3) function.
constants.name: TRANS_CUBIC

constants.description: Means that the animation is interpolated with a function using square roots.
constants.name: TRANS_CIRC

constants.description: Means that the animation is interpolated by bouncing at, but never surpassing, the end.
constants.name: TRANS_BOUNCE

constants.description: Means that the animation is interpolated backing out at edges.
constants.name: TRANS_BACK

constants.description: Signifies that the interpolation should be focused in the beginning.
constants.name: EASE_IN

constants.description: Signifies that the interpolation should be focused in the end.
constants.name: EASE_OUT

constants.description: Signifies that the interpolation should be focused in both ends.
constants.name: EASE_IN_OUT

constants.description: Signifies that the interpolation should be focused in both ends, but they should be switched (a bit hard to explain, try it for yourself to be sure).
constants.name: EASE_OUT_IN

methods.description:
Add a custom property info to a property. The dictionary must contain: name:[String](the name of the property) and type:[int](see TYPE_* in [@Global Scope]), and optionally hint:[int](see PROPERTY_HINT_* in [@Global Scope]), hint_string:[String].
			Example:
			[codeblock]
			Globals.set("category/property_name", 0)

			var property_info = {
			    "name": "category/property_name",
			    "type": TYPE_INT,
			    "hint": PROPERTY_HINT_ENUM,
			    "hint_string": "one,two,three"
			}

			Globals.add_property_info(property_info)
			[/codeblock]
methods.name: add_property_info

				Be aware that it therefore returns an angle oriented clockwise with regard to the (0, 1) unit vector, and not an angle oriented counter-clockwise with regard to the (1, 0) unit vector (which would be the typical trigonometric representation of the angle when calling Math::atan2(y,x)).

WeakRef.brief_description: Holds an [Object], but does not contribute to the reference count if the object is a reference.

WeakRef.description: A weakref can hold a [Reference], without contributing to the reference counter. A weakref can be created from an [Object] using [method @GDScript.weakref]. If this object is not a reference, weakref still works, however, it does not have any effect on the object. Weakrefs are useful in cases where multiple classes have variables that refer to eachother. Without weakrefs, using these classes could lead to memory leaks, since both references keep eachother from being released. Making part of the variables a weakref can prevent this cyclic dependency, and allows the references to be released.
WeakRef.name: WeakRef

methods.description: Set the path of the resource. This is useful mainly for editors when saving/loading, and shouldn't be changed by anything else. Fails if another [Resource] already has path "path".
methods.name: set_path

methods.name: take_over_path

methods.name: get_rid

Resource.description: Resource is the base class for all resource types. Resources are primarily data containers. They are reference counted and freed when no longer in use. They are also loaded only once from disk, and further attempts to load the resource will return the same reference (all this in contrast to a [Node], which is not reference counted and can be instanced from disk as many times as desired). Resources can be saved externally on disk or bundled into another object, such as a [Node] or another resource.
Resource.name: Resource

PopupMenu.brief_description: PopupMenu displays a list of options.

methods.description: Add a new item with text "label" and icon "texture". An id can optionally be provided, as well as an accelerator keybinding. If no id is provided, one will be created from the index.

Note that checkable items just display a checkmark, but don't have any built-in checking behavior and must be checked/unchecked manually.
methods.name: add_check_item

methods.name: get_item_ID

methods.description: Return the accelerator of the item at index "idx". Accelerators are special combinations of keys that activate the item, no matter which control is focused.

methods.description: Return the metadata of an item, which might be of any type. You can set it with [method set_item_metadata], which provides a simple way of assigning context data to items.
methods.name: get_item_metadata

FuncRef.brief_description: Reference to a function in an object.

methods.description: Set the object on which to call the referenced function. This object must be of a type actually inheriting from [Object], not a built-in type such as [int], [Vector2] or [Dictionary].
methods.name: set_instance

methods.description: Set the name of the function to call on the object, without parentheses or any parameters.
methods.name: set_function

FuncRef.description:
In GDScript, functions are not [i]first-class objects[/i]. This means it is impossible to store them directly as variables, return them from another function, or pass them as arguments.
		However, by creating a [FuncRef] using the [method @GDScript.funcref] function, a reference to a function in a given object can be created, passed around and called.
FuncRef.name: FuncRef

GridContainer.brief_description: Grid container used to arrange elements in a grid like layout

methods.description: Sets the numbers of columns in the container, then reorder its children to accommodate the new layout
methods.name: set_columns

methods.description: Returns the number of columns in this container
methods.name: get_columns

GridContainer.description: Grid container will arrange its children in a grid like structure, the grid columns are specified using the [method set_columns] method and the number of rows will be equal to the number of children in the container divided by the number of columns, for example: if the container has 5 children, and 2 columns, there will be 3 rows in the container. Notice that grid layout will preserve the columns and rows for every size of the container.
GridContainer.name: GridContainer

methods.name: int

methods.description: Cast a float value to an integer value, this method simply removes the number fractions, so for example [code]int(2.7)[/code] will be equals to 2, [code]int(.1)[/code] will be equals to 0 and [code]int(-2.7)[/code] will be equals to -2.
methods.name: int

methods.description: Cast a [String] value to an integer value, this method is an integer parser from a string, so calling this method with an invalid integer string will return 0, a valid string will be something like [code]'1.7'[/code]. This method will ignore all non-number characters, so calling [code]int('1e3')[/code] will return 13.
methods.name: int

CanvasItem.description:
Base class of anything 2D. Canvas items are laid out in a tree and children inherit and extend the transform of their parent. CanvasItem is extended by [Control], for anything GUI related, and by [Node2D] for anything 2D engine related.
		Any CanvasItem can draw. For this, the "update" function must be called, then NOTIFICATION_DRAW will be received on idle time to request redraw. Because of this, canvas items don't need to be redraw on every frame, improving the performance significantly. Several functions for drawing on the CanvasItem are provided (see draw_* functions). They can only be used inside the notification, signal or _draw() overrides function, though.
		Canvas items are draw in tree order. By default, children are on top of their parents so a root CanvasItem will be drawn behind everything (this can be changed per item though).
		Canvas items can also be hidden (hiding also their subtree). They provide many means for changing standard parameters such as opacity (for it and the subtree) and self opacity, blend mode.
		Ultimately, a transform notification can be requested, which will notify the node that its global position changed in case the parent tree changed.

constants.description: Mix blending mode. Colors are assumed to be independent of the alpha (opacity) value.

constants.description: Canvas item transform has changed. Only received if requested.
constants.name: NOTIFICATION_TRANSFORM_CHANGED

RayCast2D.description:
A RayCast2D represents a line from its origin to its destination position [code]cast_to[/code], it is used to query the 2D space in order to find the closest object intersecting with the ray.

		RayCast2D can ignore some objects by adding them to the exception list via [code]add_exception[/code], setting proper filtering with layers, or by filtering object types with type masks.

		Only enabled raycasts will be able to query the space and report collisions!

		RayCast2D calculates intersection every fixed frame (see [Node]), and the result is cached so it can be used later until the next frame. If multiple queries are required between fixed frames (or during the same frame) use [method force_raycast_update] after adjusting the raycast.
RayCast2D.name: RayCast2D

Light2D.description: Node that casts light in a 2D environment. Light is defined by a (usually grayscale) texture, a color, an energy value, a mode (see constants), and various other parameters (range and shadows-related). Note that Light2D can be used as a mask.

constants.description: Adds the value of pixels corresponding to the Light2D to the values of pixels under it. This is the common behaviour of a light.
constants.name: MODE_ADD

constants.description: Substract the value of pixels corresponding to the Light2D to the values of pixels under it, resulting in inversed light effect.
constants.name: MODE_SUB

constants.description: Mix the value of pixels corresponding to the Light2D to the values of pixels under it by linear interpolation.
constants.name: MODE_MIX

constants.description: The light texture of the Light2D is used as a mask, hiding or revealing parts of the screen underneath depending on the value of each pixel of the light (mask) texture.
constants.name: MODE_MASK

Light2D.name: Light2D

methods.description: Whether an action has an [InputEvent] associated with it.
methods.name: action_has_event

methods.description: Remove an [InputEvent] from an action.
methods.name: action_erase_event

methods.description: Return an array of InputEvents associated with a given action.
methods.name: get_action_list

methods.description: Return whether the given event is part of an existing action. This method ignores keyboard modifiers if the given [InputEvent] is not pressed (for proper release detection). See [method action_has_event] if you don't want this behavior.
methods.name: event_is_action

methods.description: Clear the [InputMap] and load it anew from [Globals].
methods.name: load_from_globals

InputMap.description: Singleton that manages actions. InputMap has a list of the actions used in InputEvent, which can be modified.
InputMap.name: InputMap

methods.description:
Returns the VehicleBody's velocity vector. To get the absolute speed in scalar value, get the length of the return vector in pixels/second. Example:
				[codeblock]
				# vehicle is an instance of VehicleBody
				var speed = vehicle.get_linear_velocity().length()
				[/codeblock]
methods.name: get_linear_velocity

Reference.brief_description: Base class for anything that keeps a reference count.

methods.description: Increase the internal reference counter. Use this only if you really know what you are doing.
methods.name: reference

methods.description: Decrease the internal reference counter. Use this only if you really know what you are doing.
methods.name: unreference

Reference.description: Base class for anything that keeps a reference count. Resource and many other helper objects inherit this. References keep an internal reference counter so they are only released when no longer in use.
Reference.name: Reference

Area2D.brief_description: General purpose area detection and influence for 2D physics.

methods.description:
Set the space override mode. This mode controls how an area affects gravity and damp.
				AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_DISABLED: This area does not affect gravity/damp. These are generally areas that exist only to detect collisions, and objects entering or exiting them.
				AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_COMBINE: This area adds its gravity/damp values to whatever has been calculated so far. This way, many overlapping areas can combine their physics to make interesting effects.
				AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_COMBINE_REPLACE: This area adds its gravity/damp values to whatever has been calculated so far. Then stops taking into account the rest of the areas, even the default one.
				AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_REPLACE: This area replaces any gravity/damp, even the default one, and stops taking into account the rest of the areas.
				AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_REPLACE_COMBINE: This area replaces any gravity/damp calculated so far, but keeps calculating the rest of the areas, down to the default one.
methods.name: set_space_override_mode

methods.description: Return the space override mode.
methods.name: get_space_override_mode

methods.description: When overriding space parameters, this method sets whether this area has a center of gravity. To set/get the location of the center of gravity, use [method set_gravity_vector]/[method get_gravity_vector].
methods.name: set_gravity_is_point

methods.description: Return whether gravity is a point. A point gravity will attract objects towards it, as opposed to a gravity vector, which moves them in a given direction.
methods.name: is_gravity_a_point

methods.description: Set the falloff factor for point gravity. The greater this value is, the faster the strength of gravity decreases with the square of distance.
methods.name: set_gravity_distance_scale

methods.description: Return the falloff factor for point gravity.
methods.name: get_gravity_distance_scale

methods.description:
Set the gravity vector. This vector does not have to be normalized.
				If gravity is a point (see [method is_gravity_a_point]), this will be the attraction center.
methods.name: set_gravity_vector

methods.description: Return the gravity vector. If gravity is a point (see [method is_gravity_a_point]), this will be the attraction center.
methods.name: get_gravity_vector

methods.description:
Set the gravity intensity. This is useful to alter the force of gravity without altering its direction.
				This value multiplies the gravity vector, whether it is the given vector ([method set_gravity_vector]), or a calculated one (when using a center of gravity).
methods.name: set_gravity

methods.description: Return the gravity intensity.
methods.name: get_gravity

methods.description:
Set the rate at which objects stop moving in this area, if there are not any other forces moving it. The value is a fraction of its current speed, lost per second. Thus, a value of 1.0 should mean stopping immediately, and 0.0 means the object never stops.
				In practice, as the fraction of speed lost gets smaller with each frame, a value of 1.0 does not mean the object will stop in exactly one second. Only when the physics calculations are done at 1 frame per second, it does stop in a second.
methods.name: set_linear_damp

methods.description: Return the linear damp rate.
methods.name: get_linear_damp

methods.description:
Set the rate at which objects stop spinning in this area, if there are not any other forces making it spin. The value is a fraction of its current speed, lost per second. Thus, a value of 1.0 should mean stopping immediately, and 0.0 means the object never stops.
				In practice, as the fraction of speed lost gets smaller with each frame, a value of 1.0 does not mean the object will stop in exactly one second. Only when the physics calculations are done at 1 frame per second, it does stop in a second.
methods.name: set_angular_damp

methods.description: Return the angular damp rate.
methods.name: get_angular_damp

methods.description:
Set the order in which the area is processed. Greater values mean the area gets processed first. This is useful for areas which have an space override different from AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_DISABLED or AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_COMBINE, as they replace values, and are thus order-dependent.
				Areas with the same priority value get evaluated in an unpredictable order, and should be differentiated if evaluation order is to be important.
methods.name: set_priority

methods.description: Return the processing order of this area.
methods.name: get_priority

methods.description: Set the physics layers this area can scan for collisions.
methods.name: set_collision_mask

methods.description: Return the physics layers this area can scan for collisions.
methods.name: get_collision_mask

methods.description:
Set the physics layers this area is in.
				Collidable objects can exist in any of 32 different layers. These layers are not visual, but more of a tagging system instead. A collidable can use these layers/tags to select with which objects it can collide, using [method set_collision_mask].
				A contact is detected if object A is in any of the layers that object B scans, or object B is in any layer scanned by object A.
methods.name: set_layer_mask

methods.description: Return the physics layer this area is in.
methods.name: get_layer_mask

methods.description: Set/clear individual bits on the collision mask. This makes selecting the areas scanned easier.
methods.name: set_collision_mask_bit

methods.description: Return an individual bit on the collision mask.
methods.name: get_collision_mask_bit

methods.description: Set/clear individual bits on the layer mask. This makes getting an area in/out of only one layer easier.
methods.name: set_layer_mask_bit

methods.description: Return an individual bit on the layer mask.
methods.name: get_layer_mask_bit

methods.description: Set whether this area can detect bodies/areas entering/exiting it.
methods.name: set_enable_monitoring

methods.description: Return whether this area detects bodies/areas entering/exiting it.
methods.name: is_monitoring_enabled

methods.description: Set whether this area can be detected by other, monitoring, areas. Only areas need to be marked as monitorable. Bodies are always so.
methods.name: set_monitorable

methods.description: Return whether this area can be detected by other, monitoring, areas.
methods.name: is_monitorable

methods.description: Return a list of the bodies ([PhysicsBody2D]) that are totally or partially inside this area.
methods.name: get_overlapping_bodies

methods.description: Return a list of the areas that are totally or partially inside this area.
methods.name: get_overlapping_areas

methods.description: Return whether the body passed is totally or partially inside this area.
methods.name: overlaps_body

methods.description: Return whether the area passed is totally or partially inside this area.
methods.name: overlaps_area

Area2D.description: General purpose area detection for 2D physics. Areas can be used for detection of objects that enter/exit them, as well as overriding space parameters (changing gravity, damping, etc). For this, use any space override different from AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_DISABLE and point gravity at the center of mass.
Area2D.name: Area2D

signals.description: This signal is triggered only once when a body enters this area. The only parameter passed is the body that entered this area.
signals.name: body_enter

signals.description: This signal triggers only once when a body enters this area. The first parameter is the body's [RID]. The second one is the body as an object. The third one is the index of the shape of the body that entered this area, and the fourth one is the index of the shape in this area that reported the entering.
signals.name: body_enter_shape

signals.description: This signal is triggered only once when an area enters this area. The only parameter passed is the area that entered this area.
signals.name: area_enter

signals.description: This signal triggers only once when an area enters this area. The first parameter is the area's [RID]. The second one is the area as an object. The third one is the index of the shape entering this area, and the fourth one is the index of the shape in this area that reported the entering.
signals.name: area_enter_shape

signals.description: This signal is triggered only once when a body exits this area. The only parameter passed is the body that exited this area.
signals.name: body_exit

signals.description: This signal triggers only once when a body exits this area. The first parameter is the body's [RID]. The second one is the body as an object. The third one is the index of the shape exiting this area, and the fourth one is the index of the shape in this area that reported the exit.
signals.name: body_exit_shape

signals.description: This signal is triggered only once when an area exits this area. The only parameter passed is the area that exited this area.
signals.name: area_exit

signals.description: This signal triggers only once when an area exits this area. The first parameter is the area's [RID]. The second one is the area as an object. The third one is the index of the shape entering this area, and the fourth one is the index of the shape in this area that reported the entering.
signals.name: area_exit_shape

Material.brief_description: Abstract base [Resource] for coloring and shading geometry.

methods.description: Set a [Material] flag, which toggles on or off a behavior when rendering. See enumeration FLAG_* for a list.
methods.name: set_flag

methods.description: Return a [Material] flag, which toggles on or off a behavior when rendering. See enumeration FLAG_* for a list.
methods.name: get_flag

methods.description: Set blend mode for the material, which can be one of BLEND_MODE_MIX (default), BLEND_MODE_ADD, BLEND_MODE_SUB. Keep in mind that only BLEND_MODE_MIX ensures that the material [i]may[/i] be opaque, any other blend mode will render with alpha blending enabled in raster-based [VisualServer] implementations.
methods.name: set_blend_mode

methods.description: Return blend mode for the material, which can be one of BLEND_MODE_MIX (default), BLEND_MODE_ADD, BLEND_MODE_SUB. Keep in mind that only BLEND_MODE_MIX ensures that the material [i]may[/i] be opaque, any other blend mode will render with alpha blending enabled in raster-based [VisualServer] implementations.
methods.name: get_blend_mode

methods.description: Set the line width for geometry drawn with FLAG_WIREFRAME enabled, or LINE primitives. Note that not all hardware or VisualServer backends support this (like DirectX).
methods.name: set_line_width

methods.description: Return the line width for geometry drawn with FLAG_WIREFRAME enabled, or LINE primitives. Note that not all hardware or VisualServer backends support this (like DirectX).
methods.name: get_line_width

Material.description: Material is a base [Resource] used for coloring and shading geometry. All materials inherit from it and almost all [VisualInstance] derived nodes carry a Material. A few flags and parameters are shared between all material types and are configured here.

constants.description: Geometry is visible when this flag is enabled (default).
constants.name: FLAG_VISIBLE

constants.description: Both front facing and back facing triangles are rendered when this flag is enabled.
constants.name: FLAG_DOUBLE_SIDED

constants.description: Front facing and back facing order is swapped when this flag is enabled.
constants.name: FLAG_INVERT_FACES

constants.description: Shading (lighting) is disabled when this flag is enabled.
constants.name: FLAG_UNSHADED

constants.description: Use the regular alpha blending equation (source and dest colors are faded) (default).
constants.name: BLEND_MODE_MIX

constants.description: Use additive blending equation, often used for particle effects such as fire or light decals.
constants.name: BLEND_MODE_ADD

constants.description: Use subtractive blending equation, often used for some smoke effects or types of glass.
constants.name: BLEND_MODE_SUB

Material.name: Material

methods.description: Set the split offset.

methods.description: Return the split offset.

methods.name: set_dragger_visibility

methods.description: Return visibility of the split dragger(One of [DRAGGER_VISIBLE], [DRAGGER_HIDDEN] or [DRAGGER_HIDDEN_COLLAPSED]).

InputEventScreenDrag.brief_description: Built-in input event type for screen drag events.

PacketPeerStream implements a custom protocol over the StreamPeer, so the user should not read or write to the wrapped StreamPeer directly.

methods.description:
Set the function to call when any body/area enters or exits the area. This callback will be called for any object interacting with the area, and takes five parameters:
				1: AREA_BODY_ADDED or AREA_BODY_REMOVED, depending on whether the object entered or exited the area.
				2: [RID] of the object that entered/exited the area.
				3: Instance ID of the object that entered/exited the area.
				4: The shape index of the object that entered/exited the area.
				5: The shape index of the area where the object entered/exited.
methods.name: area_set_monitor_callback

Set the continuous collision detection mode from any of the CCD_MODE_* constants.
